name: Ancient Lakes
caption: The Ancient Lakes Trail is a great destination for a day hike, or you can camp for the night. (Caitlin Moran / The Seattle Times)
summary: A day hike in the Columbia Basin can be a good bet if you're looking to escape Western Washington clouds.

name: Baker Lake
caption: Hikers photograph Hidden Creek from a recently repaired bridge on the Baker Lake Trail, in Mount Baker-Snoqualmie National Forest. (Christy Karras photo)
summary: When higher elevations are buried in snow, here’s an easy hike with smashing views of an iconic North Cascades mountain.

name: Bandera Mountain
caption: The view from the top of Bandera Mountain includes alpine lakes and forested hillsides. (Tan Vinh / The Seattle Times)
summary: From a crowded trailhead just off Interstate 90, butt-kicker climb to summit thins out the tenderfoot hikers.

name: Camano Island Cranberry Lake Trail
caption: Cranberry Lake, in Cama Beach State Park, was created when beavers dammed a small stream. (Brian J. Cantwell / The Seattle Times)
summary: Take an easy hike to a beaver pond teeming with wildlife, then kick back with a cold one at an outpost of a favorite Seattle brewery.

name: Carbon River Road
caption: Foot and bike traffic are the only means of transportation through the Carbon River entrance to the national park. (Erika Schultz / The Seattle Times)
summary: Here's a pick from the ‘Creaky Knees’ guide that focuses on national parks and monuments

name: Deception Pass
caption: Hikers take a photo from Goose Rock, one of the highest points on Whidbey Island. (Caitlin Moran / The Seattle Times)
summary: Weave under a historic bridge and clamber atop Goose Rock, then finish the day in the Skagit Valley’s outpost of Chuckanut Brewery.

name: Dungeness Spit
caption: Dungeness Spit is one of the world's longest sand spits. (Photo by Ken Lambert / The Seattle Times)
summary: Dungeness Spit hike offers dramatic views of water and mountains, and Chimacum’s bucolic Finnriver Cidery is a perfect spot to wind down.

name: Grand Forest Trails
caption: Enjoy the sunlight filtering through the tall trees in Bainbridge Island's Grand Forest. (Greg Gilbert / The Seattle Times)
summary: Plentiful waypoints make it easy to find your way through the maze of hikes in this multi-section preserve that’s close to civilization but doesn’t feel like it.

name: John Tursi Trail
summary: Deception Pass is our most-visited state park, but you can find solitude if you know where to look.

name: Kukutali Preserve
caption: Driftwood is strewn across beaches leading to Flagstaff Island on the Kukutali Preserve. At left is Skagit Island. (Ken Lambert / The Seattle Times)
summary: This quiet, unpopulated island, connected by a pedestrian causeway to Fidalgo Island, offers lovely views of saltwater bays and neighboring Deception Pass State Park.

name: Lake Ingalls Trail
caption: Lake Ingalls is good for fly casting because of its lack of surrounding vegetation. (Kyle Johnson)
summary: Washington’s high lakes offer fresh scenery, and you might be the only angler on the water.

name: Lime Kiln Trail
caption: Hikers check out the historical lime kiln from which this hike receives its name. (Evan Bush / The Seattle Times)
summary: A close-to-home cruiser of a hike winds through a moist forest and leads to relics of the past.

name: Middle Fork Snoqualmie River
caption: The Middle Fork Snoqualmie Park Natural Area and Russian Butte are seen in the distance from a bluff near the trail. (Steve Ringman / The Seattle Times)
summary: Rainy-day hike: Many of the draws, including Stegosaurus Butte, are within the first mile or so.

name: Oyster Dome Trail
caption: The view of the sweeping blue water from the top of Oyster Dome. (Andy Bronson Photography)
summary: Improvements include new switchbacks on a formerly steeper and slippery stretch of trail overlooking Samish Bay and the San Juans.

name: Pacific Crest Trail
caption: Lupine, Indian paintbrush and western bistort fill a meadow in the Goat Rocks Wilderness as Mount Adams dominates the southern horizon. (Terry Wood)
summary: The national scenic trail’s northern leg offers some of its grandest views. Here are some trail veterans’ favorite stretches.

name: Silver Falls
caption: Silver Falls is on the Ohanapecosh River just off Highway 123. (Steve Ringman / The Seattle Times)
summary: Another ‘Creaky Knees’ pick: an easy hike to a spectacular waterfall in Mount Rainier National Park.

name: Spruce Railroad Trail
caption: Hikers pause along the Spruce Railroad Trail edging Lake Crescent, in Olympic National Park. (Seabury Blair Jr.)
summary: From the ‘Creaky Knees’ guide: a lakeside walk on the Olympic Peninsula.

name: Tiger Mountain Talus Rocks
caption: A path between three boulders in the Talus Rocks on Tiger Mountain, Aug. 16, 2015. (Photo courtesy of Dennis Bratland)
summary: Rainy-day hike: Tiger Mountain is an urban-adjacent playground full of little delights, both natural and man-made. Talus Rocks, an intriguing cluster of giant boulders, is a favorite.

name: Twin Falls
caption: A portion of Twin Falls is seen from above the Snoqualmie River. The trailhead is east of North Bend, off Interstate 90. (Steve Ringman / The Seattle Times)
summary: Rainy-day hike: A favorite hike any time of year, with undulating elevation and a big payoff in the namesake falls.

name: Umtanum Ridge Crest Trail
caption: Central Washington University students hoof up the dusty Umtanum Ridge Crest trail. (Evan Bush/The Seattle Times)
summary: A straightforward, short and steep hike that offers beautiful views of volcanoes and wildflowers, the Umtanum Ridge Crest Trail is worth a sweaty slog through sunny canyonlands near the Yakima River Canyon.

name: Wallace Falls
caption: Fungus grows from a mossy tree trunk along a trail in Wallace Falls State Park, just north of Gold Bar, off Highway 2. (Mike Siegel / The Seattle Times)
summary: Rainy-day hike: This 5.6-mile waterfall hike is a classic, which means it can often be crowded on nice days. Here’s your chance to hike it in peace.

name: Wenatchee Crest snowshoe
caption: Wenatchee Crest Trail has minimal elevation gain and follows an old dirt road, making it a good choice for first-time snowshoers. (Caitlin Moran / The Seattle Times)
summary: A leisurely snowshoe hike and a brewery visit are the perfect way to shake off the winter blues.

name: Westside Road
caption: Mount Rainier, with Kautz Ice Cliff at the center, can be seen from Westside Road. (Courtesy of Wikipedia Commons)
summary: A good early-summer warmup hike from the "Creaky Knees" guide.

name: Wonderland Trail
caption: Near Tahoma Glacier on the west flank of Mount Rainier, people hike on Emerald Ridge on the Wonderland Trail. (Drew Perine / The News Tribune
summary: The famed 93-mile loop around Mount Rainier is more than a century old. Here are some things to know about the trail.
